awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Reversals in Polarity of the Magnetic Fields of Planets and Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic fields in the stars and planets are common features in the universe.  The individual properties of these magnetic fields vary widely, however, among all of these different objects. In our own Solar System, the Sun's magnetic field has a well-defined, periodic reversal of polarity every 22 years.  In contrast, the Earth undergoes magnetic field polarity reversals that are irregular in timing.  All planets in the Solar System except Mars and Venus have active magnetic fields, and Mars was once home to a relatively strong magnetic field.  Magnetic fields have also been observed in other stars.   Research into the causes of magnetic field polarity reversals can produce results affecting the forecasting of solar flares, as well as understanding the space environment that will affect human exploration beyond the Earth's orbit.  The investigators will develop and use new software tools to advance our understanding of polarity reversals.  The Principal Investigator and a graduate student will lead this project, which will also make many opportunities for undergraduates to join in the research.

The investigators will develop novel dynamo modeling analysis tools and incorporate them into a well-understood and highly efficient magnetohydrodynamic code to advance our understanding of polarity reversals in new dynamical regimes. These tools will allow for a multiscale analysis of polarity reversals, and enable a precise characterization of the physical processes at work in the two reversal regimes observed to date. This research has the potential to significantly alter the current view of dynamo physics by conducting one of the most detailed numerical analyses to date of the equations governing natural dynamos.

por.por_cntn:
Both the Earth's and the Sun's magnetic field reverse polarity over time. While the Sun's magnetic field reversals occur with predictable periodic cycles, the Earth's reversals are chaotic. This project has utilized numerical simulations to better understand why these differences might occur. For the Sun and other stars, we find periodic reversals to be common across a wide range of physical parameters. Figure 1 shows so-called dynamo waves from an example simulation and Figure 2 shows the corresponding structure of the small scale magnetic field. We find that the period of these dynamo cycles is consistent with the theory of rapidly rotating convection. Chaotic reversals occur only in a limited range of parameter space that is not consistent with what is known about the Earth.

Several investigations of the physics of the flows that drive these dynamos were carried out. Our studies have shown that simulations follow predictable scalings as derived from theory, allowing for comparison with natural objects such as planets and stars. The main result is that these scalings indicate that viscosity plays an important role in both the underlying small scale turbulence that drives the magnetic fields, as well as the large scale winds that develop. The predicted flow speeds as obtained from these scalings are consistent with observations, providing support for the theory. This theory may ultimately be useful for developing simplified models of planetary and stellar magnetic fields.

This research provided important training opportunities for three graduate students and two undergraduate students. Students were trained in the areas of geophysical and astrophysical fluid dynamics, high performance computing, and advanced data analysis techniques. Students were also able to build communication skills by assisting in journal article preparation and attending scientific conferences.
